meta.description: Three-week remote working trip with Hacker Paradise

alcantara.title: Alcântara, Lisbon
alcantara.description: I was set up in a rustic Airbnb in Alcântara, a hipster neighborhood in East Lisbon.

images.caption: Bunk bed - how quaint! My roomate and I did enjoy a light-filled living room and spacious backyard. The kitchen was my least favorite part because it was dark and dingy. Luckily Uber Eats meant I had to do little cooking during my time there.
I found a cute succulent at Lidl and decided it was going to be my silent companion for three weeks.
Our coworking space was located in LxFactory, a converted factories filled with shops, cafes and restaurants.
LxFactory didn't have the best food. The restaurants were a little pricey because they were targeted to tourists. However, I found this rooftop bar Rio Maravilha to be quite charming at sunset.
Toward the Tagus river there was Village Underground, an industrial junk yard repurposed into graffiti and art.

alfama.title: Alfama, Lisbon
alfama.description: The old quarter of Lisbon is a maze of narrow cobblestone streets and traditional houses meandering up steep hill from the Tagus river to the Sao Jorge castle.

images.caption: I loved peering through the gates to get a glimpse of the water in the distance.
Layers on layers of brick-roofed houses spotted from Santa Luzia view point.
Tram 28 shuttles tourists through the historic center of Lisbon.
One of my favorite spot was a rooftop bar called TOPO in Martim Moniz square. It was the perfect spot to chill with a cocktail as the sun set.
Brunch at the vintage Marcelino Pão & Vinho.
Made it to Castelo de São Jorge.
Catching sunset near Miradouro de Graça.
A trendy nightlife district that still retains an edgy atmosphere and gritty appearance.
Pink Street, the city's former red light district was transformed into its nightlife center.
We spent an evening dancing at Lust in Rio.
Nearby there were also the traditional market Mercado da Ribeira and Time Out Market food court.
The iconic Praça do Comércio. I was convinced that it was perpetually sunny in Lisbon
Took a sailing tour (with unlimited wine) and passed by the Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries) in Belém.
You could spot Cristo Rei (Christ the King) in the south (Almada city), which was inspired by the Christ the Redeemer statue of Rio de Janeiro.
I didn't visit a lot of museums in Lisbon but the tile museum was a must-see (Museu Nacional do Azulejo). Like codfish and Fado, these ceramic glazed tiles are a Portugese classic.
Panoramic view of the city from the top of Amoreiras shopping center in Campo de Ourique.
Belém Tower was the only place I visited that was West of my Alcantara neighborhood. It was located in Belém, home of the famous pasteis de Belem or pasteis de nata (egg custard tart).
Padrão dos Descobrimentos celebrates the Portugese Age of Discovery in the 15th and 16th centuries.
I had various cod dishes while in Portugal (e.g. bacalhau à brás, bolinhos de bacalhau). But the best thing I had were octopus and pork stew.
I always crave Asian food whenever I travel. I was ecstatic to finally make it to Boa Bao in Baixa (downtown), where I had really delicious pad Thai.

sintra.title: Sintra
sintra.description: A major tourist destination famed for its picturesqueness and historic palaces, castles, parks and gardens.

images.caption: My first destination was Quinta da Regaleiria, a Disney-like gothic palace.
The tour was organized by We Hate Tourism Tours, headquartered in LxFactory - highly recommended.
The palace is known for its extensive gardens and system of tunnels. The Initiation Wells were used both for storing water and ceremonial purposes.
I was definitely not lost trying to figure out the tunnel entry points.
On the way back to Lisbon, we made a pit stop at Cabo da Roca, the westernmost point of continental Europe.
The beach in Cascais was really popular on a sunny late-summer afternoon.
Every day I'd spent in Lisbon up to this point was super sunny. So imagined my surprise when my return to Sintra was shrouded in rain and fog.
There were crowds at the palace despite the bad weather. You could see why from the architecture and iconic colors.

porto.title: Porto, Portugal
porto.description: Hacker Paradise always organized a weekend trip away, and Porto was 2.5 hours away by train.

images.caption: Our walking food tour took us to the giant market Mercado do Bolhão. We sampled a lot of canned cod fish, cheese, Iberian ham, etc.
The tile on historic buildings around Porto were amazing - Almas chapel and Santo Ildefonso church.
Cats
Porto was made of rolling hills, narrow streets and expansive hilltop view. It justaposes old and new, quaint and bustling
View from top of the hill.
On the last morning before boarding the train, I visited the Porto Cathedral.
